Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £9 to Brindisi. The cobined Sea and special train fare has been reduced to £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles. During the Monsoon season the express streamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 pm and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 pm on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Army Problems.
div.p: To the many and eminent services which Lord Roberts has rendered to his country he has now added another by throwing all the weight of hie authority and experience into an effort to arouse the public to a sense of the dangerous inefficiency of the land defences of the Empire. It is an encouraging symptom that his previous utterances on this vital subject led the London Chamber of Commerce to invite him to address a special meeting, for which the Mansion-house was placed at disposal by the Lord Mayor. These is always good hope of a movement which interests the City of London to this extent, and we trust that his reception may not only convince Lord Roberts that he is producing an effect upon public opinion, but may lead other important public bodies to lend their aid. much of the difficulty of his task arises from the dual nature of the problem of Imperial defence. The public are accustomed to think of the British Army as an organisation maintained at vast expense lor the purpose chiefly of sending regular drafts to India, occasionally carrying on small frontier wars with turbulent tribes in various parts of the world, and pro viding a second line of defence for these islands. There is endless discussion of the intelligently conducted, either by military men or by the public. It resolves itself too

often into a mere shuffling about of Regulars, Militia, and Volunteers, each of which has its convinced advocates always regarding the others with a jealousy which is fatal to progress. The essential limitations of all three are. continually ignored. About our Regular Army, the cardinal fact is that it is a voluntary army, which has to go into the labour market for recruits, and that taking one year with another the number of useful recruits may be put at about 30,000. Army reformers may be clever, though sometimes they are not, but were they gifted with absolute genius they could not make 30,000 men into anything more than thirty thousand. They are always trying experiments and putting forth schemes which one and all involve the hopeless attempt to make that number do duty for a larger one. The Militia and Volunteers are counted in and scored out again, pretty much as an Oriental jeweller makes a solid ring mostly consisting of base metal, dissolves-out the bare metal, and has for remainder a ring indeed, but one which is no stronger than the original gold which suffices to form it.

There is another aspect of Imperial defence which all this peddling puts out of sight altogether. Even if the Army were made thorough-ly adequate for the purposes we have named, there would remain the question what we are to do in case our possessions are attacked by one of the gigantic armies of modern days, drawn by conscription from populations often greatly outnumbering our own. When we have counted up everything that has ever stood in front of a sergeant, we have nothing adequate for such a contest The Norfolk Commission, we have no doubt quite rightly, has declared that neither Militia nor Volunteers are fit to face the thoroughly trained soldiers of States that put most of the population through the ranks. Were they fit they could not be compelled to go abroad, and were they compelled to go there is no organisation or equipment fitted for a serious war. Taking such forces as are usually contemplated in a vague way without question of their actual efficiency, Lord Roberts tells us that for serious work, say on the frontier of India, there would be a shortage of 7,000 officers. The medical service would not suffice for 100,000 men in real war against a civilised foe. Men of sorts could perhaps be scraped together, as in the Boer war, to the number of 350,000, but that was the limit of our resources even with unfit material, while in a serious war we should need to put in the fighting line quite that number of trained soldiers and then furnish extensive reserves and reinforcements. That is the aspect of Imperial defence to which Lord Roberts desired to call attention when he said in the House of Lords that the British Army is no better prepared for war than before the South African troubles began. He had no thought of denying that reforms have been made in such Army as we have, but he was speaking of that larger Imperial defence for which we have made no preparations that can be regarded as serious.

Now what are the preparations which he regards as serious and possible. Not an army of conscripts, which he regards as unsuited to the conditions of this country, though that would be preferable to total unpreparedness wants universal training in drill and in shooting, carried out in all sorts of ways to suit all conditions of men. That would give us a population out of which we could form efficient soldiers in large numbers, with the very short preparation which the Japanese have found adequate, thanks to the practical efficiency of their education. What harm would it do to divert some of the energies of our schoolboys from games into the path of ordered exercises, which would fit them in a great emergency to save the Empire! What harm would it do the classes from which officers are drawn so to modify their education and their amusements as to make them embryo officers! Drill for everybody, familiarity with a rifle for everybody, and higher education as applied to war for all who possess superior intelligence would do nothing but good all round. No one surely can look upon the crowds of slouching figures to be seen in our streets without thinking what a pity it is that they were not taught at school to hold themselves erect. No one can consider the mental slouch of so many of his fellow beings without regretting that they were never taught alertness and discipline. What was begun in school would be willingly carried on afterwards. We should have real Volunteers with real officers; and we should have a hundred for one. The talk about militarism is cant. A citizen army never fights for the fun of it Militarism is the vice of an army irresponsibly governed, or of an army of citizens who have no voice in their own affairs. Besides, with a population trained as Lord Roberts desires, and treated afterwards as it would demand to be treated, we should inspire abroad a kind and degree of respect which would go far to curb the ambitions of militarism everywhere.

div.head: THE PEACE TERMS
MUTUAL EVACUATION OF MANCHURIA
RUSSIA RELINQUISHES LIAOTUNG>
div.p: Portsmouth (N.H.), August 15.

Articles 2 and 3 were settled yesterday. They relate to the evacuation of Manchuria, with the abandonment of Russian rights there, and the cession to the Chinese of the railway to the south of Kharbin. (Reuter)
Portsmouth (N.H.), August 15.
The Russians will benefit by the most favored nation clause in Korea.

It appears that the clause relating to the cession of the railway to the Chinese was not settled yesterday. This clause will come later. But relating to the restoration of the Chinese administration in Manchuria is settled.

Clause IV. concerning the surrender of the ease of the Liaotung Peninsula and the Blonde and Elliot Islands has been agreed upon. It is understood that the clause does not touch Port Arthur and Dalny, which are covered by a separate article. ( Reuter)
Portsmouth (U.S.A.), August 15.

The peace plenipotentiaries have adopted the first four clauses stipulating the preponderative influence of the Japanese in Korea, the mutual evacuation of Manchuria, the integrity of China, and the relinquishment of Russian rights in the Liaotung Peninsula.
The fifth clause relating to the cession of the island of Saghalien, has been postponed on account of a divergence of views. (Havas)

div.head: THE CHANNEL FLEET
STARTS FOR THE BALTIC
div.p: Portsmouth, August 15. The Channel cruiser squadrons, composed of 11 battleships and 8 cruisers, have left for a cruise in the Baltic Sea. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COTTON CRISES
MASTER SPINNERS OBDURATE
div.p: Manchester, August 15. Four-fifths of the master spinners refuse to grant the increase of wages, while the same proportion of the operatives are resolved to strike if the increase is not conceded. A strike is therefore inevitable, if the conference called by the Lord Mayor does not effect an arrangement. (Reuter)

div.head: BAD HARVESTS IN RUSSIA
EXPORT OF CORN RESTRICTED
POLISH AUTHOR SENTENCED.
div.p: Warsaw, August 15. Thé novelist Sienkiewicz has been sentenced to detention in his residence for having published a protest against the Russification of the Polish schools. (Reuter)

div.p: Vienna, August 15. The King of England has arrived. (Havas)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Tin Brindisi Mail the G. P. O. Alexandria,
will be delivered at at 9.30 p.m. to-night
Aboukir Railway-It is reported that Kharaba station on the Sidi Gaber—Aboukir line is to be renamed Maamoura.
The Shah’S Birthday. — A reception was held this morning by the diplomatic agent of Persia in honor of the anniversary of of the Shah of Persia's birthday.
Burglary at Cairo—M. Cirolli’s shop in tho Rue Clot Bey has been broken into by burglars, and over 100 watches and sole jewellery have disappeared.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Ghezireh district of Cairo during tomorrow night and at dawn of the 18th inst will be poisoned by the police.
Accident at Mafruza — A member of a repairing gang, named Mohamed el Sayed, was knocked down by a goods train yesterday near Mafruza station, and his right leg was broken.
Red Sea Lighthouses.—We have to acknowledge with thanks; the receipt of a further parcel of magazines and periodicals for the use of the employés of the Red Sea Lighthouses, from Mrs. M. G. Calumena.

The Plague—Yesterday’s plague bulletin reports two admissions to hospital and two cases at Alexandria. The new cases are a Greek boy of Bahari Bey street and a Bulgarian boy, living near the Labban caracol.

Suez Canal.—24 vessels passed through the Canal on the 12th and 13th inst., of which 14 were British, 8 German, 1 Dutch, 1 French. The receipts for the two days were frs. 527.731.83, making the total from the 1st inst. francs 3.930,645.04

The Slave Trade—The report of the Repression of Slave Trade Department for the month of July shows that manumission papers were granted to twenty-one slaves during that month. All of these were Sudanese, eleven being men and twelve women.

The Wily Hindu has made money out of Sudanese credulity. A so-called agent of the Sultan of Mascat recently appeared at Khartoum, contracted various loans .... and disappeared. Inquiries prove that the Hindu was an adventurer of whom the Mascat authorities knew nothing.

Leon Fehmi's Case—Leon Fehmi, in addition to being sentenced to one year’s imprisonment and condemned to pay the costs of the case, as we announced yesterday, has also been fined the sum of one piastre for having assaulted Mustapha Pasha Orphi, from whom he attempted to extort money.

The August Bulletin of the Union Syndicale contains some interesting ’articles, notably in the 'Causerie Agricole,’ where we observe a well-deserved tribute to Mr. Ma-chell’s campaign against the cotton worm, and some very readable notes on the rise of the price of land in Egypt.

A Woman’s Jealousy.—It is reported that a Kafr-el-Zayat native woman, whose jealousy was aroused by the love of her husband for his first wife, whom he had left for three months only to return to her again, killed him by poisoning his food. The woman, who is under arrest, protests her innocence.

Forged Diplomas. - Our Greek contemporary "Phôs” states that in accordance with the request of the Greek Diplomatic Agent in Egypt, the Greek Government has made an enquiry into the, origin of no less than four forged diplomas possessed by Greek pharmacists practising in Egypt. It appears that a regular manufactory of false diplomas exists at the University of Athens, of all places

Tram Collision.—At 8.30 p m. yesterday evening tram No. 17 had just left the halt at the Café du Nil, Rae Tewfik, and had moved on the single line section of the tramway when tram No. 12, coming from the opposite direction collided with it. Considerable material damage was done, the roof of one of the collid ing trains being wrecked. The Tramways Company informs us that no personal damage was inflicted on any of the passengers, one of whom lost a hat and stick in the accident We hear, from other sources of bruises sustained through the shock, but it appears that, whatever really occurred, no one sustained any serious hurt. We hope that the Tramways Company will lose no time in fixing the responsibility for the accident, and making a public statement of its causes.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL

div.head: CUSTOMS RETURNS FOR JULY
EXPORTS TO U.S.A. INCREASE
div.p: We congratulate the Customs Administration on the rapidity with which it has completed and published its monthly report for July. Up to the present the report has not appeared nearly so quickly, the returns for May and June, for example, appearing on or about June 25 and July 25 respectively, so that the July return is a good ten days in advance of the usual date of publication. We hope that the Administration will persist in this excellent innovation.
Turning to the figures for the past month, we note that the imports totalled LE. 1,509,986 against L.E. 1,525,104 during the corresponding month of the past year, showing a slight decrease.
The increase of the exports as compared with the July returns for 1901 is very remarkable, amounting to L.E. 342,504, the figures being L.E. 1,174,409 against L.E. 831,905 in 1904.

Taking the figures for the first seven months of the year 1904-1905 we have a decline on exports amounting to no less a sum than L.E. 1,103,293, in the present year, though imports show an increase of L.E. 732,023 between January 1 and July 31,1905, as compared with the corresponding period in 1904.

In July British imports—in which we include imports from Cyprus, Malta and Gibraltar,—were valued at L.E. 526,255, against L.E.. 526,772, in July 1904, while for tho first seven months of the year they totalled L.E. 3,760,459 against L.E. 3.525,814, showing a decided increase. The increase of French imports is proportionately even higher for the seven months in L.E. 1,160,411 in 1905 against L.E. 976,579 during the corresponding period in 1904, without counting the French Mediterranean possessions. German trade shows a huge decline for the month, L.E. 56,968 as against L.E. 86,587 for the month of July 1904, and a marked falling off in the first seven months of 1905.

The export statistics continue to show a decline. England is still by far Egypt's best customer, followed by Germany and France. The exports to the U.S.A. have sprung up from L.E. 392,230 in the first seven months of 1904 to L.E. 648,394 during the corresponding period this year, and those to Turkey show an increase both for July, and for the seven months period, owing we believe to the fact that Egyptian rice is highly appreciated in Palestine and Syria. But the fact that there is a district shrinkage in Egypt's export trade with most of her customers is explained by the lower price of cotton, which has not been counterbalanced by the increase—205,505 cantars—-in the quantity exported.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM
div.p: The following is the official note issued by the Ministry ol the Interior, giving the weekly cotton-worm reports from the provinces for the week ending last Saturday :
Gharbieh.—639 feddans belonging to 66 proprietors, have been attacked, and 479 have been cleared by 1,076 children.
Fehera.—1256 feddans, belonging to 16 proprietors, have been attacked, and 846 have been cleared by 2,523 children.
Dakahlieh.—-96 feddans, belonging to 26 proprietors, have been cleared by 282 children.
Kalioubieh.—5 feddans, belonging to 1 proprietor, have been cleared by 20 children.
Damietta.—21 feddans, belonging to 11 proprietors, have been cleared by 120 children.
The steps taken against the spread of the Nedwet el Assal continue to give good results.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
div.p: The report of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt for July contains an important note by Mr. R. B. Abdy on Egypt’s probable call on gold in 1905-6, and a well written and detailed review of Egypt’s trade for the first six months of 1905.

The note on Egypt’s trade with Damascus is of some importance, and it is gratifying to learn that the buyer at Damascus considers that Egyptian rice is the best he can get; even the Rangoon product taking seoond place.

div.head: DISCOVERY OF DERVISH DOCUMENTS
div.p: A short time back a London daily paper published from a correspondent at Khartoum the news of the discovery in a deep well at Omdurman of a large quantity of paper, including registers and books which belonged to the old Dervish Government, and expressed the opinion that some interesting finds were expected when the examination of these papers was made.

On enquiry yesterday at the Sudan office, our Cairo correspondent was informed that, so far, the examination has brought to light no documents whatever of any historical value; in fact, beyond receipts, accounts, “istimarahs, and such like papers, nothing has been found up to the present by the officials entrusted with the duty of going through the find.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO
div.p: A grand vocal and instrumental concert will be held tomorrow afternoon at the san Stefano Casino. The vocal part of the programme, which will include the famous trio from I Lombardi, is as follows:-

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: A New Method Of SALVAGE.
(from our Correspondent).
Port Said, Monday.

The raising of the sunken dredger Pharaon II is a matter of hours only. The last of the four pairs of lighten was finally put into position to-day, and was securely lashed with chains to the dredger, as were the others. All four were filled as soon as they were completed, aud after being tested, were sunk to the harbour bottom, where a small army of divers made them ready for the pumping out. The placing has been going on all the morning and I believe the pumps well be started to-day, or at latest in the morning of Tuesday.

The method used, that of converting pairs lighters into boxes by bolting their tope together, and providing piping from the reversed bottom of the upper one, through which the suction hoses will be led, is worthy of all praise. It is a very clever idea and I believe quite original. The staff of the Canal Company are to be congratulated and should it prove successful, of which there is every probability, one of the best pieces of salvage
work of the day will stand to their credit.
BY Wilhelm Meister.
CRICKET.
IL
BRITISH CRUISER FOR CHINA.
The British second class cruiser Flora,which
arrived here on Saturday, is to sail for the China station to-morrow. She was built in 1893, and is armed with eight six-inch guns, in additions to those of smaller calibre.
SCENE IN THE CUSTOMS YARD.
In connection with the case of molestation

of an Italian lady which I noted a few days ago, there was a considerable disturbance in the yard of the Custom house on Sunday, when a relative of the lady met the Arab who, it is alleged, insulted the lady in question. From words the affair become more serious, and the intervention of a number of police under Major Bonelli, and that of the Italian Consul was necessary to quell the disturbance, which attracted numbers of idlers.

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH COMPANY
div.p: Our readers will be glad to learn that the reduced tariff of one shilling per word for telegrams from Egypt to France, Algeria, and Tunis comes into force today. This rate of one shilling per word now applies to the whole of Europe.

div.head: FIERCE FIGHT WITH THE POLICE
div.p: Information having reached the police that a certain house in the Koronfish district of Cairo was used as a hashish dépôt by an Israelite called Selim Ibrahim, several agents of the secret police, the moawin of the Monski caracol, a captain of the police, and a shawish surrounded the house with the purpose of searching it. The door of the house was opened by the proprietor himself who recognized the police agents and tried to close it again, being assisted in his endeavours by his parents and some companions. A fierce struggle, in which nabouts and revolvers played a formidable part, ensued. The shawish, an Italian of the name of Pietro Giuliana, was severely wounded in the face, receiving a deep cut running from his left eye to the upper lip, and he was also very much bruised. Several others of the party were more or less severely injured before an entranoe could be effected, one of them receiving a wound in the abdomen from a revolver bullet Selim Ibrahim, who is a local subject, was arrested in the evening.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Westcott and Laurence liner S.S. Orestes which left Malta yesterday, is due at Alexandria on Saturday, with a general cargo from London.
The Moss liner Seti sailed from Liverpool, last Saturday afternoon, and is due here on the 26th inst, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S. Brittania arrived at Liverpool from Alexandria last Monday.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Oxford will sail for Liverpool on Saturday next
The S.S. Roman Prince, which left Manchester on the 18th inst., is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 29th inst, with general cargo.

div.head: ENGLAND, GERMANY AND TURKEY IN THE NEAR EAST
div.p: (Continued from August 5.)

With regard to these Christian Nationalities of the East we may say that, while before recent events that have sealed the union of England, France and Italy, they might have, in some cases, shown scruples as to aiding a military occupation of Syria on the part of the British, they know full well to-day that, for the sake of their Latin sisters and for themselves, they will have to render England all possible aid, and that on the success of her attempt to rescue them from their miserable fate, depends the future of civilisation itself, and liberty in the near East. Centuries of struggle have only won. for the Lebanon a factitious and derisory indépendance, which weakens every year under the solvents of the pernicious and futile regime of a succession of inept Mutassarrifs who are the creatures of the Porte. Its people have learnt by emigration, or in European schools, to appreciate the beauties of civilisation, but dare not do more than parade their knowledge for fear of awakening the barbarism that surrounds them, and being engulfed in its waves.

We believe that we have sufficiently demonstrated the fact that at this moment in the world’s history, an attempt by Great Britain to establish herself in Syria, with a view to preserving her threatened authority in the near East, would run no risk of being thwarted by any power or combination of powers, capable of successful opposition. What was impossible but yesterday, before the fruitful treaty of April 8, 1904, before Mukden and Tsushima, before the Franco-Italian rapprochement, and before the arbitration treaties, owing to the association of four powers France, Germany, Russia, and Turkey, all interested, each according to its own views, in maintaining the status quo in Syria, has to-day, through the dissociation that has sprung up between them, and the overthrow of the most enterprising member of the informal league, become not only possible, but eminently practicable, not to say indispensable, for the future of civilisation in the East, and the safety of the United Kingdom. Similar moments are rare in history, and rare and fleeting are the combinations of circumstances that offer suoh possibilities of success to a”bold policy. But it is essential to recognise the fact that what is easy enough to-day will be impossible tomorrow, through the modification of the position of each of the footers in the problem, notably of Turkey, and that England, if she refuses to take advantage of her position as first of the Oriental Powers, will have one day to strike her tents.

If she permit’s Von der. Goltz's plan to mature and develope, and waits in false security till the Turk has completed his railway communication from Stamboul to the Egyptian frontier, and completed too his subsidiary military reforms, her last hour will have struck and the last hour—alas ! -of civilisation on the near East. If on the contrary, she profits by the moment of grace allowed her and the marvellous chance it offers, and is the first of the powers to drive in the wedge of her influence, and, taking advantage of the example of Mohamed the Conqueror, to continue her efforts till firmly established in the Asiatic and African territories that are the bridge heads of the Suez Canal, she is saved.

Let England emulate the sagacity of Japan, and by prompt and decisive action baffle the formidable and deadly designs of her German and Ottoman enemies! Britain’s great work will be preserved from ruin, her African Empire set on a firm basis, India saved, and civilisation and freedom for ever established in the East
(Concluded).

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lewa St G. Henry Pasha, Acting Sirdar, recently paid a visit of inspection to Wad Medani, accompanied by Miralai Matchett Bey and Dickinson Bey.
H. E. Slatin Pasha, Inspector General of the Sudan, is expected to return from leave about the end of September.
El Miralai Matchett Bey, having returned from the Sudan, resumed command of the Cairo District from August 14.
El Kaimakam A. C. Grant Bey. senior inspector of the Berber province, has been retransferred to the Egyptian Army.
Captain R. Blackett, 2nd battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted leave of absence until October 7.
Ismail Pasha Sirry has left for Holland where he will spend three months.
Mr. F. B. Wynch, Manager of the Khartoum branch of The National Bank, leaves Cairo to-night for the Sudan.
Abdallah Pasha, the brother of the late Cherif of Mecca, is said to have applied to the Ottoman Government for the vacant post of Cherif.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: CRICKET.
E.T.C v. MR. DAWSON’S XL

This match was played on the A.C.C's ground yesterday and resulted in the severe defeat of the E.T.C., who won the toss but could do nothing against the bowling of H. B. Carver and P. P. Graves, both of whom came out with gcod analyses. Dawson kept wicket extremely well, and stumped two batsmen very smartly. The whole side was dismissed for 30, G. Mclean, who hit a couple of fours, being the highest scorer.

Mr. Dawson’s XL took matters fairly easily when they went in. Birley and Peel were the highest scorers, the latter playing a vigorous but streaky innings of 77. Me hit 14 fours but gave numerous chances ; none the less his innings gave his side a long lead. Of the other batsmen Lucas did best, staying in some time for a cautious 19.

The E.T.C. XL went in again at 5.15 p.m. and started so disastrously that it looked as if they might lose the match by an innings. A freely hit 90 not out by Byrne saved them and the score at the close was 56 for 7 wickets.

div.head: “ENTENTE CORDIALE.”
div.p: “Times."

Nothing can be more natural or more in accordance with the spirit of this civilisation and of the age than that two peoples who have so much in common, who know each other so well, who owe each other so much, and who esteem each other so highly, should wish to be firm friends. In the past there have been serious and manifold obstacles to such a friendship. France and England have important material interests all over the globe, and at a number of points those interests have stood in conflict. It was natural that the local repre sentatives of the two Powers in remote regions should attach an importance which sometimes was perhaps exaggerated to the particular differences at issue in their own immediate sphere. It was natural that the Govern-ments and the nations at home should support the views of their agents abroad. Distrust begat distrust, and suspicion suspicion. Neither nation desired war, but so long as these differences remained outstanding, a situation existed which put peace at the mercy of an accident, or an imprudence. Happily for both coun-tries aud happily for mankind, the conduct of French and English affairs has been in the hands of statesman who felt that a conflict between them would be an irreparable calamity to both, a grief to their friends, and a joy to their enemies. Frenchmen and Englishmen, even when the irritation between them was most acute, never forgot that, valaable as might be the actual or prospective interests which they were disputing in distant lands, they had an interest of immeasurably greater vaine at home, and that interest was and is peace.
“Standard.”

When Frenchmen feel at home in England and Englishmen in France, the era of lasting peace and a good understanding will have, indeed, commenced. French fleets have visited Spithead before, and their welcome has not been lacking in magnificence ; but the value of the present demonstration lies not in the round of public gaiety which has been prepared, but in the easy sociability which, inaugurated by the King last night, will permeate every event of the visit. Formal functions there must necessarily be ; but it is the change of seeing English cities, the English country side, and something of English life, which our visitors anticipate moat keenly. The permanent good likely to result from the visit is not worse but better assured, because no
one, for the moment, is thinking of it, but each and all are hoping that our guests may have a good time.
“Echo de Paris.”

Never will the illustrious naval port have rendered a greater homage to any nation in the world than to the French nation. The splendid demonstration now being prepared is significant for both countries. It is not merely a final paragraph added to the act of reconciliation of two nations that have been too long separated. It is above all the striking affirmation of a lasting friendship.
“Petit Parisien.”

The Englishman, is of a rather cold temperament, but when be lets himself go he does so with a vengeance, and this is just as true of public as of private life. No nation is more reserved, more self-contained, but when once the Englishman's sympathy has been won it can be counted upon.

div.head: BRITISH EAST AFRICA.
div.p: “Morning Post.”

Sooner or later the necessity for the creation of a separate department for dealing with the affaire of our possessions in Equatorial Africa will have to be recognised. No doubt, in the orthodox British manner, we shall reach that goal by stages, and Mr. Lyttelton might do worse than consider whether the time has not come to take a preliminary step in the direction of a more efficient system on the lines which have already bean sketched in these columns. But in the meantime East Africa and the non-official population must be heard. Their statement of grievances is a lengthy one, and amounts to little less than an indictment of the whole system under which they live. Even when every allowance is made for the exaggeration which may be looked for in an ex parte statement, made by men smartirg under a sense of injustice and neglect, it is impossible to escape from the conviction that there are many things in the actual condi tion of the Protectorate which merit the most earnest consideration at the hands of the Secretary of State for the Colonies. We need not stay to consider whether the system established by the Foreign Office, was suited to the requirements of the Protectorate before the advent of European settlers. It is evident that, in many important respects, it no longer meets the needs of the situation. Whether the remedies which the non-official population suggest are those best suited to remove the grievances of which they oomplain, we cannot undertake to say. But all the traditions of British Colonial administration are in favor of associating the
unofficial elements in the population with the local ad

THE FUTURE OF MOROCCO.

It is somewhat remarkable, considering the proximity of Morocco to Europe, that it is only during the last two or three years that any real activity has been shown on the part of the various European Powers to explore and exploit its commercial possibilities. The little that is so far known of the Moroccan Empire points to its becoming in the future, one of the richest of the many rich African countries. It is wonderfully fertile, especially in those provinces situated within the "Tell” region. It has rich pasturages, and although still in avery primitive condition, sheep-farming has proved itself to be a most successful pursuit. Cereal, moreover, of every description flourish, and by proper management Morocco is capable of becoming one of the world's largest granaries. Its mineral wealth is considerable, and it possesses at least three of the most important minerals from a commercial point of view— namely, iron, tin, and coal—besides lead and antimony and others. It is favored with an excellent climate, and in order to enable it to become a prosperous country, it merely re quires the reorganisation of its entire administrative system. At the present moment it is one of the most lawless and uncivilised of countries, and it is imperative that something should be done without further loss of time to bring about a change in the present state of its internal affairs.

France, Spain, and Great Britain are the Powers which have the most natural political and commercial interests in Morocco's future. France should be given a free hand as far as the reorganisation of the administration of Morocco is concerned, and in abolishing the present chaotic state of affairs and it is the joint duty of both Spain and England to loyally support France in her endeavours to effect this. If rapine and brigandage can be stamped ont, the prosperity of the country will be ipso facto assured. With regard to safeguarding the commercial interests of the four Powers, guaranteeing the independence of Morocco, viz, France, Spain, Germany, and England, it might be advisable to have a permanent Commission sitting at Tangiere for this purpose,and for each of the signatory Powers to depute a delegate to it. This Commission should also have the supervision of the Moroccan finances, and be ran very much on the same lines as the International Commission sitting in Athens. At the same time the policy of the “open door” should be most rigidly enforced, and fair play be shown to all commercial enterprises, respective of the nationality of their promoters.
THE TSAR’S “OCCULTISM.”

The secret of the Tear’s hypnotist, who caused considerable talk in Europe some eighteen months ago, is out at last. There has just died at Arbreste, in the French Department of the Rhone, a man named Philippe Landard, who enjoyed such a high repute in France for his power in magnetism that he was known as "Philippe the healer.” He was originally a butcher's assistant at Lyons, but becoming aware of his powers as a hypnotist, he began to practise magnetism, and soon made a fortune. Several years ago he visited Russia, where his fame had preceded him. While there he made some demonstrations before the Tsar’s Court. From this grew the legend.
ALBANIAN ANARCHY.

Letters received in Rome from Janina depict the condition of Upper Albania as deplorable. Law, order, and public security have entirely disappeared, and pillage and homicide prevail everywhere. Brigands prey upon the public on ever highway and line of traffic. Even the public coaches have to be guarded by armed police parties, but as the men are badly fed and paid, they sometimes render indirect aid to the brigands. In the same way public officials, unpaid and in want, levy blackmail an the public, and justice is sold with scarcely the pretence of secrecy.
ANOTHER AFRICAN REVOLT.

There has been a serions revolt of natives in Portuguese Africa, a body of 6,000 Caanhamas attacking several villages occupied by Portu-guese settlers in the district of Caponda in Angola. Most of the inhabitants were butcher-ed, and all the buildings burned. Three French missionaries of the Congregation of the Holy Ghost were carried off by the assailants, but succeeded in escaping.

THE GIANT PIG.
VALUABLE GIFT TO SOUTH KENSINGTON MUSEUM.

There are now in the Natural History Museum at South Kensington some rare specimens of the skull of the giant pig of Central Africa. These are the gift of Lieutenant R. Meinertzhagen, of the East African Rifles. Zoologists for some years past have been aware of the existence of a large pig-like animal in the Central African forests, the first account being brought by Sir H.M. Stanley, who gained his information from the natives during his Emin relief expedition of 1888-90. Sir Harry Johnston later also heard of it, and thought that the animal might be a pigmy hippota-mus. Besides the skulls, only one of which is perfect, pieces of skin were sent

The animal, it seems, belongs to an intermediate species between the wart hog and the river hog, being more closely allied to the former. Mr. C. W. Hobley, Sub-Commissioner of the Uganda Protectorate, who has also tried to obtain a complete skin and skull without success, states that the natives say that before the great rinderpest plague of 1891 these animals were very numerous in the forests of West Nandi, but the plague killed nearly all. According to them, it has occasionally attacked women sent into the forest to gather firewood.
It is hoped by the Museum authorities that a perfect specimen of the animal will be obtained, when it will be publicly exhibited.
A WOMAN ON SHOP-GAZING.
NOT A PLEASURE BUT A PRETENCE

The unsympathetio man will never understand why women find an innocent enjoyment in shopping and window gazing ; and only women will believe there are times when shopping means anxiety more than pleasure. As one lady explains: “I simply had to pretend to look in a shop window till I felt able to go on, otherwise I should have fallen down. This was through sudden attacks of dizziness in the street. I am forty years of age, and would not complain of ordinary indispositions, but really I did not know what to do in my agony. I know now, for in Dr. William's pink pills for pale people I found renewed health and complete relief.”

The speaker, Mrs. Barnacle, 200, Great Lister street, Birmingham, added : “I feared to eat anything, for I was a martyr to indigestion. I was often sick, and had such giddy turns going upstairs that at times I almost fell backwards. On getting out of bed I invariably felt faint. Nor did my troubles end there. The least exertion made me breathless ; my liver was sluggish ; and altogether I fell into a low, weak state through anaemia. My lips were bloodless and my cheeks saffron coloured. For two years I did not know what it was to feel well, though treated at two Birmingham hospitals.

“But this is how I found my cure. I read in a pamphlet the plain statement of one who had been cured by Dr. Williams’ pink pills, so putting aside ordinary medicine as useless, I began these pills. I felt a decided improvement from one box. Giddiness and indigestion became a thing of the past I could enjoy meals without suffering afterwards, and as the pills supplied new blood so all the signs of anaemia vanished, and I could do my work without feeling exhausted. I know now there is new strength for women in Dr. Williams’ pink pills.”

The quiet recommendation of so many ladies is eloquent proof of the high opinion held by them of Dr. Williams’ pink pills, which supply strength and new blood, and are invaluable to maid and matron. They have cured Anæmia, indigestion, palpitations, consumption, pains in the back, neuralgia, nervous disturbances, and the other ailmeuts that women try to disregard ; also rheumatism, St. Vitus’ dance, sciatica, paralysis, and locomotor ataxy. Dr. Dr. Williams’ medicine co., Holborn-viaduot, London, will forward one box, post free, for two shillings and nine pence, or six boxes for thirteen and nine. NOTICE.

The General Administration of the Egyptian Wakfs informs the public that fifteen plots of land, of which two are situated at Ibrahimieh and are known as Nos. 192 and 452, six at the place called “Cleopatra,” bearing the numbers 78, 167, 201, 202; 203, 816, and the other seven at the place called “Abou Nawater,” bearing the numbers 4 of the square 21, 8 or the square 22, 10, 12, and part of 7 of the square 25, 1 of the square 28, and 12 of the square 32 are connected with the Wakfs of Sidi Gabr and el Ansari.

A hekr tax is payable on the said plots by virtue of just claims. Therefore, the Administration, not knowing at the present the holders of the said plots, has had sign posts planted on them. It therefore invites all interested persons to present themselves at the Delegation of the Wakfs of Alexandria, Rué elMtroalri, within three months time from this date, furnished with documents establishing their rights of possession in order to pay the amount of hekr due. Should any one fail to present himself in that time, the Administration will dispose of the said lots of land, as being their true and lawful proprietor.

NICOSIA & ITS SURROUNDINGS
(From a Correspondent.)

It is well to spend at least a week in Nicosia in order to see the sites of the town, and to make the several excursions that are of interest around. But during the spring and early summer the climate is so delightful, that many will wish to remain in this quaint old town for a long period.

The most important excursion from Nicosia is the drive to Kyrenéa, the northern part of the island, which is charmingly situated at the foot of the mountains, 16 miles by road from Nicosia. With this can be combined a drive up to the mediaeval abbey and monastery of Bella pais, about an hour's distance up the slopes of the mountain, to the latter through groves of olives and carob trees, the latter of which simply abound in this part, and whose fruit is exported to Manchester and elsewhere iu large quantities. They say that this fruit forms the basisof the nourishment in Mellin’s and Morley s food.

This ruin is the finest in the whole island. It is absolutely unique in its situation. The cypress trees around its gates are far-famed, and the view of the peaks of Hilarian (to the west; from the roof of the cloisters is probably unsurpassed anywhere, especially at sunset. The whole landscape of the wooded mountain slopes, the Caramanian sea beyond, and the Anatolian hills, rising up like a wall behind it, makes a magnificent picture. Rider Haggard of it as the finest he had ever seen.

Thia view is best obtained from the pulpit window in the refectory. This monastery, like many other fine buildings in Cyprus, dates back from the time of the influences of the Lusignan dynasty, to whom King Richard I. sold the island on his return from the crusades, after having vainly tried to reduce it to order, by handing it over to the Knights Templar, during his absence. His connexion with Cyprus will be touched on when we come to Limassol.

The best description of the monastery is found in Mr. Enlart’s "L’histoire de l’art Gothique et la Rénaissance en Chypre,” which book can be obtained on loan from the club at Nicosia. One English lady, who lived at and was enamoured with Kyiénia and its environs, says that the most beautiful time of all to see
Belia-pais is by moonlight. The stars peeping over the mountains and out at sea must be simply lovely to look upon.

The next day the Venetian fort must be inspected early, a pass having been obtained from the Commandant of the Police on the previous evening. Then a drive should be taken to see Lapithos with its perennial stream, corresponding to Kythréa on the other side of the range. The picturesque village lies nestling under the hills to the west of Hilarian and Kyrenéa. All lovers of architecture should then drive down a narrow lane to the sea-side, where will be found a sweet little bay of ancient fame, and the church and monastery of Ache ripiton. The interest of this church lies in its being one of the rare instances of a building shaped like the Jerusalem cross, and consequently possessed of double transepts. The western portion and the porch are Gothic, but the rest is Byzantine. It is a pity that this gem of an ancient sanctuary is kept so unclean by the Greek priest, who inhabits the place ; I think it is probably more thickly populated by insects than any church I bave seen. The priest, as is usual,knows nothing whatever about the building or its history. The tourist has yet to produce in Cyprus a demand for informing guides returning fur lunch to Kyréuia,a distance of 12 miles from Laputhos, which takes about

two hours each way, the pass should then be climbed, as it was descended the previous day. At the rest house near the top, a ride on mules, or a rough walk, should be take to the castle of Hilarian (40 minutes) while the carriage waits. If mules are required they can be ordered iu Kyrénia beforehand and sent on to the rendezvous. The normal price for a mule per diem in this part of the is-land is two shillings. The path is very steep iu places and the panoramic views are magnificent. The animals will have -to be discarded at the foot of the last climb, which is a good deal steeper than the ascent to Carisbrooke Castle (I. of W.). The idea of utilising the rock of such a precipitous crag for the walls of one’s home is very suggestive of the character of the inmates. But when one reads that Queen Charlotte lived here, when in fear of the bastard James, her illegimate brother, who seized the throne of the island that rightly belonged to her and her delicate boy, one is amazed at the daring of the woman. The drop is simply precipitous for 1,000 ft. and the sea 3,000 feet below seems close at hand. From the top of the steps, now ruined, can be seen Bella-pais through a shoulder in the opposing hill. And one cannot help contrast ing the two ; the rough and rugged haunts of the Lusignan Queen, with the chaste and yet imposing home of those religious men of old. How delicate was their taste ! How ex quisite their sense of proportion, and of art

How noble was the pile they reared on the mountain side, so well-founded and finished that the high and massive frontal wall still stands intact while Hilarion is fast perishing. It is an allegory which speaks of the different characteristics and aims of the state and the church in those mediæval days. Each could look upon the other. But the one was an abode of terror, the other of prayer and peace, and it is obvious which has lasted longest and best amid all the changing scenes of Cypriot history.

The valley of Kythréa has already been described, in my last article. It is reached by an interesting drive of eight miles through the plain that surrounds the capital. But when once the drive is over, the valley well repays a visit.
The site of the ancient Idalion (Dali) is well worth a visit if the visitor has time. This can be approached either from the Larnaca or Limasol road, about ten miles to the south of ; the city.

The walks and short drives around the capital are delighted. The Abbot of Kykkon, the most famous Greek monastery in the Island, has a charming garden about 1 1/2 miles out of Nicosia which he is always delighted to show to Englishmen. He is a thoroughly cultured and enlightened man, and appears to have used his wisdom to the great advancement of the financial value of the monastery’s property.

The High Commissioner's grounds are within an easy walking distance, while all the southern approaches to the town are lined with beautiful avenues of eucalyptus trees, which grow in this lovely climate at an extraordinary rate. All these avenues, and the trees which now adorn the city moat, have been planted since the British occupation.

The sights in Nicosia itself are many, though difficult to find, as few regular guides are available for the purpose. But the residents are very kind in giving visitors the information they require, and those in the island interested in antiquities gladly welcome any kindred spirits.

The ancient Cathedral of St. Sophia, like the one at Famagusta, is well worth a visit, and if possible it should be paid on a Friday about 11.30 a m., so as to witness the midday prayers of the followers of the Prophet. The sight is more picturesque than the corresponding one in Constantinople, as the dress of the villagers, who come in to market and to prayers on Fridays from all the country round, is much more picturesque. A good view can be obtained from the gallery in the north transept, to which both sexes are admitted. As the Qiblah faces almost due south from Cyprus, it is fixed in the southern transept, whither at the appointed time the Imam and the faithful gather. The carpets have lately been renewed, and combined with the garb of the worshippers make a very impressive sight.

As I have already said the building is Gothic, and was built by the Lusignans in the 13th and 14th centuries. The eastern part is the older of the two, the porch being more decorated than the nave and aisles, which are quite austere in character. It is a great pity that the Turks have disfigured the east end, by making an entrance in the apse and adding sundry open gratings in the walls which have weakened the structure.

Opposite the southern entrance to the northern porch, and across the road, is the Greek church of St Nicholas, which is now partly used as a grain store, and partly for collecting antiquities. It used still further to be profaned by being employed as a market for bargaining, but that era has, happily, passed away. As with all true Greek churches there are no traces of side altars. The patterns on the door are evidently copied from foreign designs. If the visitor has time, a short visit should also be paid to Yeni Jamia, and the Armenian church which has some interesting French epitaphs in the nave.

When Mr. Jeffrey, the honorary curator of the antiquities in the island, is in residence, he will gladly show the tourist over the Museum. At present this place is in a wretchedly housed condition, and hardly ever visited, but though it contains very little ancient pottery of value, it has some most interesting specimens of Greek and Mediæval art. Unfortunately Cyprus, like Athens, has been largely denuded by the explorer, and Cesnola and Richter have carried away a great deal to America and Germany respec tvely. A large number of duplicates are said however to be piled up in Larnaca awaiting the day when the Government can spare some money to property preserve its anti quities.

Lastly, plenty of exercise can be obtained by joining the club during one’s visit. Golf tennis, etc., are the order of the day, and when dinner is over and the moon gets up and the mountain breezes blow with their spicy and bracing force, the Anglo Egyptian marrvels that so few of his compatriots have found their way across the water to Cyprus and how little the recuperative powers of its climate, and the value of the land as a sana torium close at band is realised by English doctors in Egypt.
FORTY YEARS AGO.
ENGLISH AND FRENCH VI8ITS EXCHANGED.

It is a fact worth recalling, in connection with the visit of the French fleet to British waters, that exactly forty years ago, an Anglo-French festival was held at Portsmouth on much the same lines as those on which the late fête has been carried out. As was the case in 1865, the British warships in the first place paid a visit to the French shores. Cherbourg was then the place chosen as the most befitting to do justice to the “friends of France.” Only a few years previously additional fortification had been made at Cherbourg. When the work was commenced it was intended as a menace to England, but when completed by Napoleon I. in 1858, it was celebrated by a visit to the place by our late Queen Victoria, when the most pacific assurances passed between the two Sovereigns.

During the stay of our ships at Cherbourg, everything that was possible was done to entertain our men, and, as characterised the recent visit, there could not have been more cordiality or marks of esteem displayed.

At a banquet given by M. de Chasseloup Laubat Minister of Marine, to the Lords of the English Admiralty, Rear-Admiral Dacres, and the principal Naval and Military officers, His Excellency, in the course of a long speech, made the following remarks :—

“Gentlemen,— I propose to you the health of Her Majesty Queen Victoria, It is a great honor, and a real satisfaction to me, to pro-pose this toast to-day. It is a very great honor, for I come here in the Emperor’s name to welcome the representatives of the British Navy, and I thank them, with the French Navy, for having joined us on the fête day of our august Sovereign. It is also a very sincere satisfaction to me, and this feeling should be shared by every sincere friend to his country and humanity. It is a still greater satisfaction to see this cordial and fraternal union in a port which has already witnessed the meeting of the Queen and the Emperor. Thank God, gentle-men, the time of hostile rivalry is past ; emula-ion alone remains in all that can advance the cause of liberty and civilisation in the world. Believe me, that will be a grand and noble page, in which, narrating the reign of our Emperor and your Sovereign, history shall tell how, entering upon an entirely new era, our flags no longer meet but to open in union new and vaster horizons to human activity, and how, in our disinterestedness, we summon all nations to share the reward of our efforts. That will be a noble page, also, which shall how old prejudices eradicated from the hearts of the two nations, and their manufactures hand in hand, advancing unceasingly to diffuse prosperity among all men, thus displaying their wonders in those splendid tournaments to which we by turns invite the workers of the world. Yes, gentlemen, freedom of the seas, the pacific contests of labour, and the beneficent conquests of commerce, such is the signification of these two noble flags to-day united before us. May God ever protect them, and for you, gentlemen, may He preserve to you your gracious Sovereign. “To Her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain !”
After this toast, which was received with applause, the Duke of Somerset spoke as follows

“Gentlemen,—I have heard with great pleasure the toast proposed by the Minister of Marine, as well as the speech by which it was accompanied. All Englishmen will feel a strong sentiment of gratitude in learning that upon this auspicious day, in the midst of this select assembly, the first toast proposed by the French Minister was the health of the Queen of England. We accept it as a proof of the cordial amity the Government of France, and I trust the entire nation, feels for our gracious Sovereign and our country. I reply on the part of the British Government, and I feel confident that I also express the views of the great majority of the English people, when I say that we are actuated by the same senti ments with regard to the Sovereign of France and the French people. We wish that the good understanding which now exists between the two countries may be of long duration. To the health of the Emperor and Empress and the Imperial Prince. Long live the Emperor I’
The foregoing speeches are sufficient to show the mutual feelings which then existed

On the return visit being made by the French Fleet about a fortnight later, a pro gramme worthy of the occasion was arranged, On the morning of the 29th of August, the French Fleet hove in sight, and the Master Attendant proceeded to the Solferino, accom-panied by pilots for the different ships to conduct them to their appointed berths. The Solferino, on approaching Spithead, saluted the Admiralty flag with nineteen guns, which was returned by the senior officer. The “Reine Hortense,” followed by the Os borne, then proceeded into harbour. As she passed the Spitbuoy, the Victory saluted the flag of the Minister of Marine with 19 guns, having the French flag at the fore, and manning yards as the Reiue Hor tense passed. The other ships in harbour also manned yards at the same time. When the last ship of the French Squadron had anchored, the Solferino saluted the British flag at the main with 21 guns. This salute was returned immediately by the garrison, gun for gun. After the French Squadron had an chored, the Rear-Admiral commanding the English Squadron visited the officer command ing the French squadron, who afterward returned the visit. Later, the Minister of Ma rine and his staff, with the flag officers and captains of the French Squadron, were invited to a private dinner by the Duke of Somerset The following day (August 30), the Neva establishments were visited, and a dress dinne

was given at the Royal Naval College to the Minister of Marine .and officers of the French Squadron. The toasts, “The Emperor of the French,” "The Queen of England.’’“The French Navy,” and The British Navy," were proposed. and on the health of the two Sovereigns being drank, the ships of both squadron fired a Royal salute and then illuminated. On the 31st a visit was paid to our ships. September 1 was noteworthy, for a brilliant ball, given by the Admiralty to the French officers. The departure of the fleet was made on September 2. The weather during the whole of their stay was everything that could be desired. A correspondent who went on one of the French vessels says that he heard very good English spoken by the majority of the French tailors, and always with the most sincere desire to afford any information that might be interesting.

Commenting on the visit,‘The Globe" of the day remarked: ‘There need be no reason why such friendly reunions should not oftener occur, and, indeed, it may almost appear a matter of surprise that they have not taken place before, considering how near we lie to each other. The meeting of the fleets is a demonstration of mutual respect and friendly feeling on the part of the brave services of two great nations, whose political relations are known to the world, and whose common interest in the perpétuation of peace and friendship it needs no accredited public instructor to demonstrate.”

After the return to France of the fleet, the “Moniteur du Soir” published a long article, of which the following are a few extracts : ‘The Imperial squadron has returned in England the visit paid to France by the British fleet, and has experienced at Portsmouth a reception worthy of that the English flag had received at Cherbourg. The Emperor's Government is not the first Administration in France which has wished to keep up the relations of confidence and friendship with the Cabinets of London. The good relations of France and England are founded upon mutual interests. There exists at all times between them a further tie in the conformity of their principles in m
POLITICAL RETIREMENTS IN CANADA.

Political retirements are the order of the day in Canada. Sir Wilfrid Laurier is losing two of his veteran Ministers, Sir Richard Cartwright and the Hon. R.W. Scott. The latter has been in public life for more than half a century, and his name has been prominently identified with educational and temperance legislation. Another Ministerial vacancy will be created by the approaching elevation of the Hon. Charles Fitzpatrick, Minister of Justice to the Chief Justiceship of Quebec.

The Conservatives are losing Sir Mackenzie Bowell, formerly Prime Minister of the Dominion, and during recent years leader of the Opposition in the Senate. Sir Mackensie is eighty-two, an age at which he thinks he ought to hand over the reins of leadership to younger hands. He sat twenty-fire years in the Canadian House of Commons, and has spent a dozen years in the Senate. He was one of the most trusted advisers and colleagues of the late Sir John A. Macdonald, the ‘ Canadian Disraeli,” who ruled the Dominion for seventeen years. After the death of Sir John Macdonald, Sir John Thompson dbecame Prime Minister. He died with tragic suddenness at Windsor, while on a visit to Queen Victoria, and Sir Mackenzie Bowell then became Prime Minister. He is a native of Suffolk, a oounty that supplied another Prime Minister to Greater Britain, in the person of Sir Gordon Sprigg, of Cape Colony.
CORSICA’S NEW CÆSAR.

France can dispense with her monarchs, but she finds it necessary to retain a courtier, whose office is permanent. This office is held by M Paoli, the official of the Protocol, as he is styled, the introducer of Ambassadors, the gentleman usher, without any rod, to all Sovereigns who may visit Paris. Presidents and Ministers come and go, but Paoli stays on for ever, and upon questions of courtly etiquette his word is law. Within his own sphere, he is as autocratic as the Tear. The departure of the Shah aud the arrival of the King of the Hellenes almost clashed, but Paoli saw one to the frontier and was smiling at his post to receive the other as if he had bad nothing else to do. That is one of Paoli’s little secrets. The clash had been almost, but not quite. Paoli had seen to that, as he always does. One of the curious things about Paoli—most Parisian of Parisians —is that he is not a Parisian at all, but the native of a little village in Corsica— La Porta, whither he dreams of taking his rest on the dawning of some Utopian day when he can be dispensed with.
FRONTIER ARTILLERY

Whatever may be the truth about the diplo matic situation in Morocco, information reach ing Paris from Alsace Lorraine represents Ger many as energetically pushing forward impor tant changes of armament on the frontier. The heavy fortress artillery, is especially being overhauled. The big guns of the armoured turrets a of the three forts known as the Kaiserin, Kron-prinz, and Haeseler, at Me'z, are now being re-placed by Naval guns of the newest type,and of longer range than the present heavy artillery. The three forts command the French strategic railways Pagny Nanay, Pagny-CoDfbns, Lon gnyon, and Verdon, and coold easily prevent all communication between Nancy and Verdon. These more powerfal guns entail, of oonrse, an important strengthening of the emplacements. Everything is to be completed by the end of September.
BURIED ALIVE WITH A CORPSE
THE SEQUEL TO A WEIRD VILLAGE DANCE AT MIDNIGHT.
A pope, or Russian village priest, has been buried alive by a mob of peasants in the Crimea, says a telegram from Odessa to the “Express.”

The people had ascribed the prolonged drought which has ruined their crops their season to the death of a certain old man who had been .regarded as a wizard, no rain having fallen since his burial in March last.

According to the popular superstition, it was necessary, in order to appease the sorcerer's spirit, that his remains should he exhumed at midnight, and, after being sprinkled with holy water by a priest, replaced in the grave.
Accordingly on Sunday night a procession of villagers, headed by boys and girls carrying torches and accompanied by fiddlers and flautists playing dismal dirges, set ont for the cemetery.

The body of the dead wizard was duly ex-humed, and placed ,in a sitting posture against a tree, around which forty or fifty of the peasants danced a weird dance to the accom paniment of the village musicians.
In the midst of the curious ceremonial Father Constantin, the village pope, arrived, and up braided them for their superstition.

The crowd at this grew indignant Some among them who were under the influence of vodka, shouted that he was the real wizard, as the spirit of the dead man had entered into his body. The priest was accordingly seized, and despite his shrieks for mercy was hurled by four of the men into the reopened grave, the remains of the corpse being flung in after him with earth and stones.
REVIVING ANCIENT NORMANDY.

The fêtes of the Souvenir Normand, which are being held at Caen, are part of a general movement which is as familiar in Great Britain as it is in France- The obverse and counterpart of the modern tendency for large differences of race to become less marked is the tendency for the smaller differences inside the great homogeneous economies to be revived and cherished. Thus in Great Britain there is the revival of the Irish language and the, growing insistence on the fact of Welsh nationality by means of the Eisteddfod and other channels of expression, and the numerous, societies in London which prevent the micro-, scopic patriotism of each country from losing itself in a colourless human ocean. So it is in France. No province has remained more faithful to its customs and legends than Normandy. Paris is the great centraliser of France. All the provinces, conscious of their own existence therefore resist, but none more heartily than Normandy. The people of Normandy do not regard even the Frenchmen of other provinces as true Frenchmen. Those who are not Normans are horsainst that is to say, “outsiders.” How strong is the tie which binds all those who have the singularly exclusive good fortune to be Norman is proved, by the distance from which the devotees have, come to the fêtes—not only from England, Scotland, and Ireland, but from Scandinavia, Canada, Sicily, and Russia. Of all the Norman ancestors, William the Conqueror was the greatest. No procession is complete without him, and the difficulty which Frenchmen and Englishmen must feel in adjusting their claims to proprietorship is just one of those things which can be left only to the inspiration of the place and the good humour of the moment

Présent* : MM. Ahuied Bay Byoub, L. Bscjffier, Dr. Schiess Bjy, Mmsour Bey You sef, G. Zirvodachi, membres, A. Wilner, socré taire p.i.

Les immondices déposées à Ghebel Guilleh devront être brû’ées an fur et à mesure de leur transfert : cette opération devra se faire parti entièrement de nait, au moyen de tranchées,et des mesures devront être prises pour activer la combustion par l'emploi de matières iotlatn niables.

LES MESSAGERIES MARITIMES

Pendant l’exercice 1904, clos de 30 novembre, les parcours accomplis par les navires de cette Compagnie n'ont atteint que 851 736 lieues marines, les grèves qui se sont produite à Marseille ayant suspendu le fonctionnement des services aa départ de ce port pendant dix semaines. En 1903, l’exercice ne comprenant quell mois, les parcours s’étaient élevés à 842.905 lieues.

Les recettes de toute nature ont fourni an total de 67.365.992fre., dans lequel les produite des lignes (passagers et marchandises) figurent pour 50.165.180 fr. Comparativement aux résultats de 1903, ces chiffres font ressortir □ne augmentation de 2 millions dans les recet tes générales, dont 1.444.000 fr. viennent à l’actif des produits de l’exploitation. L’ensemble des dépenses a été représenté par 59.367.999 fr;, en accroissement de 1.100.(00 fr. sur les résultats de 1 exercice précédent, bien que le chapitre da charbon ait accusé une diminution de 800.000 franc?, qu’il faut attribuer moins a la rédaction d J prix initial de la houille qu'a l'abaissement du fret payé aux navires qui l’ont transportée dans les dépôts de ia Compagnie.

L’excédent des recettes sur les dépenses a atteint 7.997.993 fr., sur lesquels 4.283.871 fr. ont été portés aa compte d'amortissement du matériel naval. La solde dispouiblo, aprèe prélèvement de 1a somme nécessaire au service des obligations, a permis la distribution d’un dividende de 10 francs aux actions ordinaires.
Commentant ces résultats, le rapport administratif présenté à la dernière assemblée géné-rale dee actionnaires espère que l’année 1905 beneficiers de nouvelles réductions au titre du
charbon, dont le prix de revient, malgre les abaissements successife qui se sont produits
depuis 1902, ressort encore h 4 fr. plus par tonne qu'en 1896. Le rapport ajoute :

‘Si 1904 ne peut pas être oonsidéré oomne un exercioe complet à raison de l’insuffiMnce des parcours exécutés, il a en cependant* «apporter toutes les charges et dépenses fixes qui correspondent à one période de doux3 mois. C’est h cette sitaation spéciale qn'il y a lien d’attribuer ponr la plas grande part les diffé-reçues que fait ressortir le rapprochement des comptes d’exploitation de 1903 et de 1904. I<w avons en à faire fooe 4 toutes ces char
sans recevoir les compensations à attendre de? produits qu’aurait procurés la pleine exécution -les services.

“Di us ces conditions, vous considérerez sans doute, avec nous, qu’il est très heureux que l'économie obtenue sur le chapitre “Charbon” d’une part, et la progression des recettes d’antre part, nous aient mis en situation de vous preseuter des résultats qui se tradaiseut, en tomme, par un million de mieux qu’en 1903.’

Envisagée à un point do vae d’ensomble, l’orgai isation des services n’a pas subi de modifient ions appréciable! pendant l’année 1901. On do t signaler toutefois que la Compagnie, aprèî iccord ave; le département des colonies a étenio jusqu’aux Nouvelles-Hébrides la na vigation du bateau affecté à la ligue annexe de Sydney à Nouméa.
Eu 03 qui concerne la partie do la navigation qui se fait sous le régime des contrats postaux

il a été satist ait, ou 1901, aux obligations im posée! par les conventions. Pour les services les plus importants, oeux do l’Indo-Chine et é^l’A istralio, dont les itinéraires sont calcalé-sur la bise de 14 nœids, la vitesse réalisée, en moyenne annuelle, a été de 15 nœuds 08 poor los lignes principales de l’Iado Chine et de 14 nœadsOl poar celle de l’Australie et de la Nouvelle Calédonie. Dans la direction de l’Océan Indien, où la vitesse contractaello ost do
12 nu|ids, les paquebots out fourni nue moyenne de 12 nœuds 11.

Dans l’intéressaut discours qu’il a prononcé après la lecture du rapport, l’honorable M. André Lebon, président du Conseil d’administration des Messageries Maritimes, s’est exprimé en ces termes au sujet des perspectives de l’exercice actuel:

‘‘Ndus touchousA trois ou quatre jours prè3, à la clôture du premier semestre de l’exercice 1905, ht à l’heure précise où je vous parle, nos recettes purement commerciales sont on pro grès de pins de cinq millions sur celles de l’année dernière a pareille date. D’autre part, les primes à la navigation que nous avons acquisps dépassent do plus de un million celles dont nous avions bénéficié l’année dernière à pareille époque. Cela fait environ, tant en recettes commerciales qu’en prime?, un excédant de six millions et demi en faveur de 1905.

“Il est vrai qu’il y a à imputer sur ces six millions et demi les dépenses afférentes à environ 50,000 lieues marines, qui ont été parcourues eu plus, mais même eu faisant cotte détalcetion, une partie considérable, partie très considérable, mais dont je me garderai bion de préciser lo chiffre, demeure acquise en recettes nettes a votre exploitation. Je souhaite de tout cœur ijue cette situation se maintienne, mais il me serait impossible de m’eu porter garant, encore; qae votre personnel s’y emploio de son mieaxj

“Notre industrie dépend de tant d’éléments intérieurs et extérieurs, qu’il faut noos résigner a vivre au jour le joar. Cependant, si cette progrosaioQ continue, et encore une fois tom uf/i efforts tendent à ce bat, il sera très aisé do donner pour l’exercice 1905, aux actions de priorité, le dividende statutaire de 5 %, et d'assurer le même dividende aux ancienne! actions ordinaires, tout en entrant très largement dans la voie très sage, très judicieuse, qui vous a été tracée par MM. les Commissaires aux comptes.

"Gui, il faut renforcer vos amortissements, il faut doter largement votre fonds d'assurance. Le dividende est une chose très appréciable, je le reconnais très volontiers, mais la valeur intrinsèque de l’action n’est pas une chose négligeable non plus, et lorsqu’on améliore son capital, on travaille tout autant pour soi que lorsqu’on améliore son revenu.”

Au 1er mai 1905, le matériel naval ou service se composait de 67 paquebots ou vapeurs de charge, jaugeant brut ensemble 298,295 tonneaux et ayant une force de 228,950 chevaux v'apenr. Eu outre, 2 navires, jaugeant respectivement 7.200 tonneaux, étaient en cours de oonstruotion.
