div.head: DERNIERE HEURE
div.p: (Clôture de la Bourse Khédiviale 1h. p.m.)
Cours de l’Association des Courtiers en Marchandises
OUR PARIS LEITER.
(From our Correspondent.)
Paris, August 8.

Frenchmen continue to talk and write with enthusiasm of the Anglo-French fêtes at Ports-mith. We are far from the days of the vitriolic articles against England, the violent squibs and caricatures. All that is forgotten in the splendid demonstrations of amity at Brest, Cowes, and Portsmouth. Auspicious name, that of Portsmouth, says one writer to-day. In the American Portsmouth the negotiations for an honorable peace are being conducted by the Russian and Japanese plenipotentiaries. At Portsmouth on the Solent the French and English fleets meet to consolidate the friendship begun at Brest.

Admiral Caillard, Commander-in-Chief of the french Northern Squadron now at Portsmouth, who has been appointed by his Majesty King Edward VII. an Honorary Knight Grand Cross of the Most Distinguished Order of 8t. Michael and St. George is barely fifty-nine years old. He first distinguished himself in the naval contingent which assisted in the defence of Paris during the German invasion in December, 1870. On the 21st of that month he was wounded grievously at Le Bourget, and next day he was promoted to be a lieutenant iu the navy. He was then in bis twenty-fourth year. He was subsequently captain of a despatch-boat in the Pacific, second in command of a cruiser under Admiral Courbet iu China, and commander of a battleship. Admiral Caillard was for a time Chief of the General Staff of the Navy, bat resigned this office for the command of a division of the Mediterranean Squadron, and took part iu the Mitylene demonstration. Three years ago he became Vice-Admiral, and was appointed to the command of the Northern Squadron, which, in the opinion of competent judges, he has raised to a high state of efficiency. Here in Paris the Admiral is hailed now as the man of the day, as his squadron ia being received in so splendid a manner at Portsmouth, and as he is taking so prominent a part in the consolidation of the “entente cordiale”. The honours conferred on Admiral Caillard and his colleagues and subordinates of the French navy by King Edward are much appreciated here.

The French naval manœuvres in the Mediterranean have been of considerable interest, and Admiral Fournier, who has acted as "admiralissimo,” has won golden opinions. It is yet too early to disengage any lessons of practical value, but some points may be noted. The tactical exercises have had the object of investigating new battle formations, and it appears to have been concluded that those formations were best, and least liable to mask the fire of one ship, or division,by the position taken by another, which had undergone least change in the presence of the enemy. The value of the autonomous groupes conjugét increased, as tho officers in command gaiued greater confidence in occupying the positions indicated by the circumstances. The idea has been to test the system of independent, but related, divisions of ships operating for a common object. The submarines are understood to have been very successful, but, of course, the battleships have placed themselves iu position to be attacked. On one occasion the Korrigan, a sister of the unfortunate Farfadet, well placed on the line of approach of the squadron, succeeded in torpedoing the Brennus, which was the leading ship, without being perceived, aud emerged at a distanoe of 200 metres. The officers and men of the Korrigan were warmly to congratulated on their success, especially in view of the anxious period through which they had passed, owing to the sad disaster to the sister vessel. The torpedo flotilla attacked the squadron near Bizerta on a later occasion, but the night being clear with bright moonlight, they were unsuccessful. The final review was a very successful event.

It may be remembered that the Superior Council of the French navy recommended, as the force adequate to the requirements of France, the constitution of five squadrons, each composed of 6 battleships with 4 reserve ships, five divisions of 3 armoured cruisers with 3 reserve cruisers, 12 second-class armoured cruisers with 6 as a reserve, 6 scouting vessels, 1 destroyer for each ironclad with 6 for the Far East, 58 torpedo craft for torpedo boat and submarine divisions, with 15 as areserve. Under this programme the French fleet would in 1919 muster 486 nuits. There remain to be constructed 11 battleship*, 1C armoured cruisers, 6 seoond-class armourer cruisers, 6 scouting vessels, 66 destroyers, a large number of submersibles and submarines, and 50 torpedo boats. The annual cost would not exceed for new construction £4,840,000, and a margin would thereby be left for the Payment of the vessels now under construction. The estimates for 1906 provide for the laying down of 8 battleships, 10 destroyers, and 20 submersibles. The battleships to be begun next year will have a displacement of about 3,000 tons more than the Kèpoblibne class, and will carry four 12in. guns, twelve 9 4in., sixteen 12pr. semi-automatic guns, and eight 6pr., also semi-automatic. They will have a speed of eighteen knots. The destroyers will be of the Claymore type, but a little larger. The submarines or submersibles will have a displacement of from 400 to 500 tons. The navy estimates for 1906 provide for the vote of credits amounting to about £13,000,000

Parisians have, during the past few days, been much interested in what might be de ecribed as the rise and fall of Jaluzot. Jalazot is the name of the managing director of the Printemps, one of the best-known bouses in Paris of the "universal providing" order, and as he belongs to the race for which money-making has no secrets, he has within, the past ten

years been a power to reckon with in a oapital which worships the man with the money-bags. 1 have heard a story, which is not very edifying as to how M. Jalazot first obtained the money to start in business, and he has never treated his employés in a manner that would justify the Printemps being taken as a model by workmen’s organisations. Bat be has made money, and although he has pocketed thousands of pounds from English customers, no sheet in the world—one cannot, call them papers—has heaped, more virulent abase on the English, and told more lies about our countrymen than the “Patrie” and the “Presse,” two organs of the gutter press belonging to M. Jalazot. This Hebrew speculator succeeded, some years ago, in getting himself elected as a deputy in the French Parliament, but I can find no record of any signal service that he has rendered to his adopted country. Not content with his earnings from the Printemps warehouse and the two “rags” he runs, he must needs try conclusions with the sugar brokers on the Bourse de Commerce. Thia time, however, he met those who could not be taken in with flashy wares or spurious sentiment. He ran op against business men who knew him, and had little liking for him, and the result has been disastrous for the Israelitish speculator. Now he cries out that he is ruined. He did not mind if others were ruined, but now that his own purse feels the pinch, he does not like it. Parisians, however, are not likely to waste much sympathy on M. Jalozot They have seen his kind before, and they will hardly believe that he is ruined. He has lost money, of course. But he has no intention of submitting to his passing ill-fortune. And at this present moment, I am certain he is looking round for some other means of making money in the future as easily as he has made it in the past

One of the most recent developments of the system of police identification methods of M. Bertillon, who has done so much in that direction, is the “spoken portrait.” The idea is by a minute analysis of the face from a photograph to so describe a man that even if you never saw him you would recognise him at once from the analytical details supplied. The nose, for example, is divided into three general categories, large, medium, and small, which in turn are subdivided into concave, rectangular, and convex. The ears, the lips, and other features are treated in the same way, and the eyes are the subject of very elaborate description. The details thus obtained are added to a dossier containing the thumbprints and other human documents concerning criminals, and the result is a personal reoord which leaves a prisoner, who has once been in the hands of the police, very little chance of passing unrecognised. That the system has been proved to be a serviceable one is evident from the fact that in the Paris police force M. Bertillon's latest development of the “spoken portrait” has been made a subject of compulsory study, and the members of the force are taught to recognise each other from the analysis of the photographs furnished to them.

There are various ways of launching a new magazine. This is the method adopted by the publishers of the latest Parisian review, “Je sais tout” M. Georges Daniel, a well known Paris journalist, wrote for this magazine an article entitled “La tournée des grands-ducs.” The article was accepted by the editor, but the author was considerably surprised when it appeared to find that it was signed, not by his name, but by that of an author with some reputation, M. Jean Lorrain. M. Georges Daniel wrote to M. Jean Lorrain protesting, and the latter at once replied, recognizing in the most unconcerned fashion that the editor of “Je sais tout” had, as a matter of fact, requested him to contribute an article on “La tournée des grands-ducs.” He had replied that he had not the time, and thereupon he had been informed that no refusal would he accepted, and that his task would be facilitated by means of ‘ documents' that would bo famished to him. The “documents” were, it appears, the article of M. Georges Daniel. M. Joan Lorrain “resigned” himself to the proposed plan, but he protests that ho was not aware that his signature was to be apposed to the article of a confrère. And he terminates his letter, couched in charming language, by offering to his oon-frère all his regrets, and the assurance of his distinguished consideration. A few days later M. Daniel recieved from the manager of “Je sais tout” a letter asking him to call at the offices of the magazine, and when he put in an appearance there he learned that he had been accused by the editor of an attempt at blackmail. An exchange of seconds followed. To the seconds of M. Daniel those of the editor denied the accuracy of the accusations for which an excuse, or “reparation par les armes,” was demanded, but he recognised having said that “the habit of the firm was to attach the signatures of well-known writers to articles written by those of less notoriety.” Now the public is warned, and has only itself to thank if it is deceived. Bat the practice which has just been exposed in connection with “Je sais toot” is, I am informed, the recognised custom in most publishing houses in Paris, when writers with a name do not themselves write the articles attributed to them. The conclusion of the foregoing incident will probably be heard in the Law Courts.

At the present moment, when the Esperanto Congress at Boulogue-sur-Mer has brought the question of a universal language to the front again, it is interesting to learn that if we cannot hit upon a tongue which will serve for humanity the world over, we may still accomplish something in the way of facilitating communication between people of different languages. The Swiss are a practical race, and one of their latest achievements is the creation of a telegraphic code destined to serve travel lers of all nationalities in the selection of

apartments. A curious prospectus which I have received contains certain reflections which will appeal to any man of common-sense. The Swiss hotel keeper has said within himself; “I must make it easy for everybody to communicate with me, and for that purpose I shall draw up a code of easy words, which shall be significant of much, and not to be mistaken. The average man, when be wants to telegraph for rooms at a hotel, has to spend much time and money, and even then he is not always understood. I shall show him how he may avoid all trouble.” And so the International Telegraphic Hotel Code is the result. “Alba” means a room with one bed, “arab” a room with two beds, “abeo” the same with three beds, etc. The central letters in these code-words words have no importance. Only the first and last letters are of value. The first letters indicates the number of rooms, the last the number of beds. Four formulae are reserved for the hour of arrival, “Granmatin” means that you will arrive between midnight and seven in the morning, “matin” between seven o’clock and midday, “sera” between midday and seven o’clock, and “gronsera” between seven in the evening and midnight Once yon know the code, all you will have to telegraph if you want to say : “Reserve me for-to-morrow two one-bedded rooms for one night ; we shall arrive between seven o'clock a.m. and midday,” will be “De main belab pass matin.” Could anything be easier? But it is not very euphonie.

The Paris Sunday is an institution which never fails to interest the visitor from England, and even more the visitor from Scotland. A great deal has been said about the Continental Sunday, and. as usual, those who know least have had most to say about it. We know what Sunday is like at home. In Scotland it is apt to be a dreary round of uninteresting religions functions, engaged in, first of all, because it is the Sabbath, and, secondly, because centuries of tradition have taught us that the Sabbath must be devoted to all that is dull and irksome. In England, if it is not quite so cheerless, it is at least a day upon which most of os have to do things we would rather not do, or, at least, upon which we are deprived of those things- we want most. The Nonconformist conscience broods over everything, and—if it does not rain—the sun shines upon a people whose faces and demeanour are eloquent confirmation of the charge that, if Sunday be a pleasure, and surely it is meant to be, then we do, indeed, take oar pleasures sadly.

On the Continent it is otherwise, and by otherwise I do not mean that, as some would lead you to believe, the day is given over to liberty and licence. Nothing of the kind. There are those in Paris—jaataa there are in London or Glasgow—to whom release from work means alcohol and saturnalia, but they are an infinitesimal minority. And when I drove through the Bois de Boulogne lately with a Scotchman and his wife, and watched the Parisians enjoying the Sunday in their own characteristic fashion, he remarked : “If this is the Continental Sunday, then I have nothing to say against it” And he added that what surprised him mostt was the fact that, although the wineshops, cafés, and brasseries were wide open, and were well patronised, no one seemed to be intoxicated. “I have not seen a single drunk man,” he said. “And I have rot heard any bad language.” He would not probably have recognized it if he had, but still, I was able to assure him that he had heard much less than if he had been in the vicinity of many a crowd of my own countrymen. We left the centre of the city and travelled to the Porte Maillot, the most popular entrance to the wood, by the “Tabs,” and although the train was crowded uncomfortably there was no rude pushing and shoving, no inhuman and ungal-lant elbowing-out of women and children so that the lords of creation might take their places. The Frenchman is a philosophic per-son, and if he does not get the first train he waits for the next and if two or three have no room for him he consoles himself by grumbling, and going somewhere else. He does not fight.

We are a pugnacious race, and if we do not get what we want, we want to have it out with someone. Not so the Frenchman, and in his never mind, indifferent attitude he very often chooses the better part He does not think that the matter is worth losing his temper about and most times he is right. He argues that he has come out to enjoy himself, and it would be poor enjoyment to begin by putting himself in a bad mood. So instead of the overcrowded train he takes a 'bus or a tram-car, or he hires a “taxametor,” and when he reaches the splendid wood that the Paris Municipality maintains for his enjoyment he arrives in a good mood, and he, and his wife and children are ready to smile and laugh and feel contented at everything that happens.

If it be a workmen's family, they have brought little, light wood seats with them,and while paterfamilias and materfamilias squat on these the chicks run about on the grass and chase the elusive butterflies Or the father gets out his fishing rod, and there he sits and angles while mother takes the little ones for some milk and cakes. And when the sun goes down and it is time to return home for the evening meal, it is a happy, if tired, company that makes its way once more towards the city. The Bois de Bonlogoe crowd on a Sunday is not exclusively composed of poor folks. At this time of year, of course, the wealthy are not numerous in Paris, but last Sunday they were not all at the seaside or in the mountains, and the humble perambulator, and the modest donkey-chaise were frequently passed by elegant broaghams and snorting automobiles. I my friend if be had remarked anything wrong in tbe Continental Sunday. “No," was his reply, “I think we have something to learn from the French."

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
London, Ang. 7th.

Under the auspices of the Kaiser, the German agitation to close the Baltic against the war ships of this country finds a ready echo in the press of the Fatherland, but without any practical result so far as this country is concerned. The Channel Fleet will go through its manœuvres, let it please our cousins or not. Old William of Prussia, who, with the assitance of England, laid the foundations of the German Empire, tried on the same game with Denmark in the long ago, and signally failed. The German scheme of to-day has not even the merit of originality. A quarter of a century ago the Iron Chanoellor invented the 4'pin-prick policy” by which he hoped to drive England into a sort of alliance. Whilst the object was legitimate enough the mode of procedure was rather singular. Bismarck’s idea was to annoy England all over the world and thus worry her into accepting German friendship, or German hostility. Germany seized part of New Guinea, the*Cameroon!, etc, etc, in pursa-anoe of this policy,bat Salisbury was more than a match for the German, and all that the latter gained was several useless oolonies,one of which has cost a tidy sum in men and money in the past few months, and is likely to cost more, and, what was worse, the kindly feeling which Britons felt for their “cousins” has gone the way of many another friendship. The good feeling between Franoe and Great Britain has simply set Germany crazy, and the main object of her present polioy is to upset that good feeling, the basis of which was so happily laid by our gracious sovereign, King Edward the Peacemaker. Another unlooked result of this policy is that England has concentrated an enormous naval force within a few hours steam of the shores of the Fatherland.

Sir A. Berkley Milne, Bart, a well-known north country officer, has been appointed second in command of the Atlantic Fleet from the 25th inst This gallant officer entered the Royal Navy in 1869, served in the Trans-kei campaign 1877-78, in the Zulu War, as aide de camp to Lord Chelmsford, including the battle of Ulundi, where he was wounded, and in the Egyptian Campaign, 1882, including the battle of Tel-el-Kebir. He was latterly employed as rear-admiral in command of the Royal yachts.

The 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers will leave Malta on the 16th November for Egypt. The battalion is due at Alexandria four days later. It relieves the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, which goes to Chabuttia, India.

The British battalion and detachments, stationed at Khartoum, in the future will be under the supervision and command of the Governor of the Sudan, who will communicate direct with the War Office on all matters relating to them. This is a step in the right direction, and another move io decentralisation, which has long hampered official life.

It is announced that that the Khedive’s decoration, granted for the operations against the cannibal Niam-Niams, in the Southern Bahr-el-Ghazal is not to be issued to the Imperial officers employed in the expedition. Why?

The Asseye is the first transport to leave Southampton for Bombay this trooping season. She is due to leave there on the 6th September, and her principal freight will be the 17th Lancers, under the command of Lieutenant Colonel B. P. Portal, D.S.O.,with Major N. T. Nickalls second in command. The Asseye is due at Bombay on the 28th following. On her return voyage she will convey to England time expired men and various details.

The battleship Venerable, Capt, A. J. Hen niker-Hugban, arrived yesterday at Sheernesa to complete preparations for her departure for the Mediterranean Station to rehoist the flag of Vice-Admiral Sir H. T. Grenfell

div.p: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
